abstract: By securing the backing of the Communications Workers of America, AT&T appears to be shoring up political support as it prepares for tough regulatory scrutiny of its T-Mobile deal.
snippet: By securing the backing of the Communications Workers of America, AT&T appears to be shoring up political support as it prepares for tough regulatory scrutiny of its T-Mobile deal.

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: With AT&T agreeing to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, the strategic options for Sprint Nextel have become more limited.
snippet: With AT&T agreeing to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, the strategic options for Sprint Nextel have become more limited.
lead_paragraph: With AT&T agreeing to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, the future of Sprint Nextel just got fuzzier.

headline.main: T-Mobile Deal Leaves Sprint’s Future Unclear

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced and Jenna Wortham

abstract: For investors, AT&T’s deal to acquire T-Mobile USA for $39 billion offset concerns about rising oil prices.
snippet: For investors, AT&T’s deal to acquire T-Mobile USA for $39 billion offset concerns about rising oil prices.
lead_paragraph: Corporate mergers and receding fears over Japan’s nuclear crisis helped global markets rise on Monday.

headline.main: Dow Soars Above 12,000 on AT&T Deal for T-Mobile
headline.print_headline: Dow Soars Above 12,000 on AT&T Deal for T-Mobile

byline.original: By Christine Hauser and Bettina Wassener

abstract: Deutsche Telekom investors celebrated the proposed T-Mobile sale, a deal that allow the telecommunications giant to shed a subsidiary that has caused it so much difficulty.
snippet: Deutsche Telekom investors celebrated the proposed T-Mobile sale, a deal that allow the telecommunications giant to shed a subsidiary that has caused it so much difficulty.
lead_paragraph: In agreeing to sell its T-Mobile USA unit to AT&T for $39 billion, Deutsche Telekom will finally shed a subsidiary that has caused the German telecommunications giant considerable difficulty.

headline.main: T-Mobile Sale May Close Tough Chapter for Deutsche Telekom

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: Part of the game will be for AT&T to show to regulators that the acquisition of T-Mobile is a net gain for consumers.
snippet: Part of the game will be for AT&T to show to regulators that the acquisition of T-Mobile is a net gain for consumers.

headline.main: The Regulatory Risk in the AT&T Deal

abstract: AT&T’s proposal to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion is the latest in a long line of telecommunications mergers to raise controversy in Washington.
snippet: AT&T’s proposal to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion is the latest in a long line of telecommunications mergers to raise controversy in Washington.

headline.main: AT&T Deal Joins a History of Antitrust Fights

abstract: Until Apple introduced its highly popular device in 2007, Deutsche Telekom had been generating rising sales from its American operation.
snippet: Until Apple introduced its highly popular device in 2007, Deutsche Telekom had been generating rising sales from its American operation.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Deutsche Telekom’s announcement over the weekend to sell its American wireless unit, T-Mobile USA, to AT&T for $39 billion ended a decade-long foray into the American market that was undermined, in part, by one big event: the advent of the iPhone.

headline.main: How the iPhone Led to the Sale of T-Mobile USA

abstract: On Monday afternoon, shares of Sprint were down nearly 16 percent, to $4.26, as investors fretted about the fate of the nation’s third-largest carrier.
snippet: On Monday afternoon, shares of Sprint were down nearly 16 percent, to $4.26, as investors fretted about the fate of the nation’s third-largest carrier.
lead_paragraph: With AT&T moving to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, investors are fretting about the fate of Sprint-Nextel.

headline.main: Shares of Sprint Down on AT&T Deal with T-Mobile

abstract: The $20 billion commitment to AT&T is the second-biggest bridge loan offered worldwide since 2000, according to Thomson Reuters.
snippet: The $20 billion commitment to AT&T is the second-biggest bridge loan offered worldwide since 2000, according to Thomson Reuters.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes of AT&T’s $39 billion bid for T-Mobile, a Wall Street giant left its mark on one of the biggest deals to emerge since the financial crisis.

headline.main: JPMorgan, the Lender Behind the T-Mobile Deal

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: William T. Winters, a former top executive at JPMorgan Chase, hired Joseph C. Novarro as chief operating officer for his new advisory firm, Renshaw Bay.
snippet: William T. Winters, a former top executive at JPMorgan Chase, hired Joseph C. Novarro as chief operating officer for his new advisory firm, Renshaw Bay.
lead_paragraph: William T. Winters, a former top executive at JPMorgan Chase, has hired Joseph C. Novarro as chief operating officer for his new advisory firm, Renshaw Bay, according to two people with direct knowledge of the appointment.

headline.main: Renshaw Bay Hires Chief Operating Officer
